t: John 21
Jesus’s Third Appearance to the Disciples
After*p this, Jesus revealed himself again to his disciples by the Sea of Tiberias. He revealed himself in this way:
Simon*p Peter, Thomas (called “Twin”), Nathanael from Cana of Galilee, Zebedee’s sons, and two others of his disciples were together.
“I’m*p going fishing,” Simon Peter said to them. “We’re*p coming with you,” they told him. They went out and got into the boat, but that night they caught nothing.
When*p daybreak came, Jesus stood on the shore, but the disciples did not know it was Jesus.
“Friends,”*r Jesus called to them, “you*r don’t*r have*r any*r fish,*r do*r you?”*r “No,”*p they answered.
“Cast*rp the*r net*r on*r the*r right*r side*r of*r the*r boat,”*r he told them, “and*r you’ll*r find*r some.”*r So they did, and they were unable to haul it in because of the large number of fish.

The disciple, the one Jesus loved, said to Peter, “It is the Lord!” When*p Simon Peter heard that it was the Lord, he tied his outer clothing around him (for he had taken it off) and plunged into the sea.
Since they were not far from land (about a hundred yards away), the other disciples came in the boat, dragging the net full of fish.
When*p they got out on land, they saw a charcoal fire there, with fish lying on it, and bread.
“Bring*r some*r of*r the*r fish*r you’ve*r just*r caught,”*r Jesus told them.
So Simon Peter climbed up and hauled the net ashore, full of large fish — 153 of them. Even though there were so many, the net was not torn.
“Come*rp and*r have*r breakfast,”*r Jesus told them. None of the disciples dared ask him, “Who are you?” because they knew it was the Lord.
Jesus came, took the bread, and gave it to them. He did the same with the fish.
This was now the third time Jesus appeared to the disciples after he was raised from the dead.
Jesus’s Threefold Restoration of Peter

When*p they had eaten breakfast, Jesus asked Simon Peter, “Simon,*r son*r of*r John,*r do*r you*r love*r me*r more*r than*r these?”*r “Yes,*p Lord,” he said to him, “you know that I love you.” “Feed*rp my*r lambs,”*r he told him.
A second time he asked him, “Simon,*r son*r of*r John,*r do*r you*r love*r me?”*r “Yes,*p Lord,” he said to him, “you know that I love you.” “Shepherd*rp my*r sheep,”*r he told him.

He*p asked him the third time, “Simon,*r son*r of*r John,*r do*r you*r love*r me?”*r Peter*p was grieved that he asked him the third time, “Do*r you*r love*r me?”*r He said, “Lord, you know everything; you know that I love you.” “Feed*rp my*r sheep,”*r Jesus said.

“Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r when*r you*r were*r younger,*r you*r would*r tie*r your*r belt*r and*r walk*r wherever*r you*r wanted.*r But*r when*r you*r grow*r old,*r you*r will*r stretch*r out*r your*r hands*r and*r someone*r else*r will*r tie*r you*r and*r carry*r you*r where*r you*r don’t*r want*r to*r go.”*r
He said this to indicate by what kind of death Peter would glorify God. After saying this, he told him, “Follow*r me.”*r
Correcting a False Report
So*p Peter turned around and saw the disciple Jesus loved following them, the one who had leaned back against Jesus at the supper and asked, “Lord, who is the one that’s going to betray you?”
When Peter saw him, he said to Jesus, “Lord, what about him?”
“If*rp I*r want*r him*r to*r remain*r until*r I*r come,”*r Jesus answered, “what*r is*r that*r to*r you?*r As*r for*r you,*r follow*r me.”*r

So*p this rumor spread to the brothers and sisters that this disciple would not die. Yet Jesus did not tell him that he would not die, but, “If*r I*r want*r him*r to*r remain*r until*r I*r come,*r what*r is*r that*r to*r you?”*r
Epilogue
This*p is the disciple who testifies to these things and who wrote them down. We know that his testimony is true.
And*p there are also many other things that Jesus did, which, if every one of them were written down, I suppose not even the world itself could contain the books that would be written.
